question_text: The United Nations has declared 2024 the International Year Of Camelids. The decision has been taken to highlight the significant importance of camelids in the lives of people across the world. y A Camelid refers to any of the even-toed ungulates of the family y Camelidae. E.g. camels, llamas, alpacas, guanacos, and vicuñas. y They are known for their remarkable adaptations to arid and high- y altitude environments. y These ungulates can be classified into two major groups: the Old World y and the New World. y The Old World Camelids, found in northern Africa and central Asia are y the true camels, such as the dromedary camels (one-humped camel) y and the Bactrian camels (two-humped camel) y The South American Camelids (New World Camelids) include the modern y llamas, alpacas, guanacos, and vicuñas. Wild populations of South y American Camelids, such as vicuñas, inhabit the high-altitude regions of y the Andes Mountains....

y It is located in the western corner of Nilgiris Plateau in the state of y Tamil Nadu. y It is a part of the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve. y It is sandwiched between the Mudumalai National Park and the Silent Valley National Park. y It was established with the prime motive of conserving its keystone y species – the Nilgiri Tahr. y It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was formerly known as Nilgiri Tahr National Park. y It is also home to Mukurthi Peak (2,554m), the fourth highest peak in the Nilgiri Hills. Vegetation: y The majority of the landscape in the reserve is covered with shrubs and mountainous grasslands. y The areas are covered with sholas and lush green tropical grasslands. Flora: y Sholas, Gaultheria fragrantissima, Helichrysum and Berberis tinctoria, Rhododendrons, Cinnamon, Mahonia, Satyrium, Raspberries etc. Fauna: y Nilgiri tahr, Indian elephants, Nilgiri Langur, Bengal tiger and bonnet macaque etc....

Karman Line y Located at 100 km (62 miles) above sea level, it is an imaginary line that demarcates the earth’s atmosphere from space. y It was established in the 1960s by a record-keeping body called the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI). y Though not all scientists and spacefarers accept it. Anything traveling above the Kármán line needs a propulsion system that doesn’t rely on lift generated by Earth’s atmosphere—the air is simply too thin that high up.In other words, the Kármán line is where the physical laws governing a craft’s ability to fly shift. Anyone who crosses this line qualifies as an astronaut....

question_text: Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate Change submits proposals for Wetland City Accreditation under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands for cities of Indore, Bhopal and Udaipur. y The Ramsar Convention during COP12 held in the year 2015 approved a voluntary Wetland City Accreditation system. y It recognizes cities which have taken exceptional steps to safeguard their urban wetlands. y It also recognizes the importance of wetlands in urban and peri- urban environments y This voluntary scheme provides an opportunity for cities that value their natural or human-made wetlands to gain international recognition and positive publicity for their efforts. y Since Ramsar COP13, 43 cities from 17 countries have been officially recognized as “Wetland Cities”. Three nominated cities include y Indore: Founded by Holkars. Sirpur Lake. y Bhopal: Bhoj Wetland. y Udaipur: Located in Rajasthan, the city is surrounded by five major wetlands, namely, Pichola, Fateh Sagar, Rang Sagar, Swaroop Sagar, an...

y Phosphorus in wastewater is a major contributor to harmful algal blooms in water bodies around the globe. y Algal Biofilm (RAB) system by Gross-Wen Technologies is an emerging technology. y In the RAB system, phosphorus-laden algae are cultivated in wastewater attached to a revolving belt. y The grown algal biomass can then be harvested from the belt and dried for use as agricultural fertilizer or as feedstock for the manufacture of biofuels and bioproducts. y This process can help close the phosphorus-cycle loop by recycling and reusing the phosphorus in wastewater, decreasing demand on limited minable phosphorus resources....

Kachchhi Kharek, indigenous dates of Kutch, become Gujarat’s fruit to get GI tag Kachchhi Kharek, the indigenous variety of dates of Kutch, has become the second fruit of Gujarat to get a geographical indication (GI) tag from the Controller General of Patents, Designs and TradeMarks (CGPDT) of India. Kachchhi Kharek Features y Dates grown in Kutch are harvested at the khalal stage, the stage when fruits have matured, accumulated sucrose, and have turned red or yellow but are still crisp. y Kachchh is the only place around the globe where fresh dates are economically cultivated, marketed, and consumed. y There are around two million date palms in Kutch today and around 1.7 million of them are seedling-origin palms of deshi (indigenous) varieties. y The area accounts for more than 85 % of total date palm cultivation in India. These dates in Kutch have to be harvested at khalal stage as they can’t withstand moist weather....

NASA says Greenland’s glaciers have lost much more ice than previously estimated and this could hold-term consequences for ocean water levels. y Most of the ice loss came from below the sea level in the fjords on the periphery of Greenland. y Most of the ice loss came from below the sea level in the fjords on the periphery of Greenland. y The ice sheet in Greenland lost about one-fifth more ice mass in the last forty years than previously estimated. y Icebergs are falling into the ocean at an accelerating rate, and a majority of the glaciers on the landmass have retreated significantly. y However, the additional ice loss only has an indirect impact on sea levels, but it could have massive implications for ocean circulation in the future....

This is the first ever lithium exploration and mining project by a Khanij Bidesh India Ltd (KABIL) , government owned entity KABIL was formed in 2019 to identify, acquire, develop and process strategic minerals overseas for use in India. y Argentina is a part of the “Lithium Triangle” (region in the Andes mountain including Bolivia and Chile). y These countries are believed to contain over 75% of existing known lithium reserves. y Other notable players are Australia, China and the United States. y China dominates the supply chain of lithium. y India is dependent on other countries for its lithium demand. y It is a lake with a pH value usually between 9 and 11. y High carbonate concentration, especially sodium carbonate, is responsible for the alkalinity of the water. y It may also contain a high concentration of sodium chloride and other salts making it saline or hypersaline Lake. y These are highly productive ecosystems compared to the freshwater lakes. y These are the most productive aquatic environments on Earth because of the availability of dissolved carbon dioxide. y They occur naturally in both arid and semi-arid areas. Examples Of Soda Lakes y Africa and Asia have the highest number of soda lakes. Most of the soda lakes in Africa are located in Eastern Africa, especially in Kenya, Tanzania, and Ethiopia. y Lake Natron in Tanzania is one of the most outstanding soda lakes in Africa y India and China have the highest number of soda lakes in Asia. y Some of the soda lakes in Asia include Lake Van(Turkey), Tso Kar Salt Lake(India), Pangong Salt Lake(India), and Lake Zabuye(China)....

Senegal’s Pink Lake is on the verge of disappearing. Lake Retba y It is also known as Lac Rose (the Pink Lake). y Location: It is located north of the Cap Vert peninsula of Senegal, northeast of Dakar. Why is it pink? y The pink coloration is due to the proliferation of halophilic green algae (living in a salty environment), Dunaliella salina, which contain red pigments. y The alga is associated with halophilic bacteria of the genus Halobacterium. y When salinity is high, algae with red pigments thrive, and when salinity is low, they give way to other algae rich in green pigments....

It is an ancient system that could bring water to dry areas. Some of Africa’s dry areas face serious water shortages due to minimal rainfall. An ancient system of drawing water from aquifers, the “qanat system”, could help. Qanat system y It is an ancient type of water-supply system, developed and still used in arid regions of the world. y It taps underground mountain water sources trapped in and beneath the upper reaches of alluvial fans and channels the water downhill through a series of gently sloping tunnels. y The qanats have been used for centuries in arid and semi-arid parts of north Africa, the Middle East and Asia, where water supplies are limited. y It’s known by a variety of names, “foggara” in north Africa, “falaj” in Oman and “qarez” in parts of Asia. y Some of the region’s qanat systems, like those in Iran, are protected under heritage status....

y A scientist from the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) recently discovered a new plant species of ‘wild okra’ named ‘Abelmoschus Odishae’. Abelmoschus Odishae y It is a new plant species of ‘wild okra’ y It was discovered in a moist deciduous forest in Bansapal block in Keonjhar district, Odisha. y It can be used for hybridisation to create a better variety with high disease resistance. y It can also play a vital role in widening the genetic base of okra. y It is a perennial shrub up to 5 meters high...

Rising global temperatures could lead to an increase in the nesting range of green turtles in the Mediterranean Sea, as per a study in Scientific Reports. Green Turtle y The Green turtle is one of the largest sea turtles and the only herbivore among the different species. y They are in fact named for the greenish color of their cartilage and fat, not their shells. y They graze on seagrasses and algae, which maintains the seagrass beds and makes them more productive. y These species migrate long distances between feeding grounds and the beaches from where they hatched. y Distribution: Green turtles are found mainly in tropical and subtropical Waters around the world (Atlantic ocean,Pacific Ocean and Indian Ocean) Conservation status 1. IUCN: Endangered 2. CITES: Appendix 1 Threats: Habitat loss, fisheries by catch and illegal trade etc....

y A Chinese state company has reportedly bagged the multi-million dollar contract to redevelop an international port in Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands. y This development has prompted a cautious response from neighboring Pacific countries. The contract is part of a larger $170 million project funded by the Asian Development Bank, which includes upgrading roads and wharves in the Solomon Islands. The China Civil Engineering Construction Company (CCECC) was reported to be the only bidder for the port redevelopment project. y The announcement of this contract comes nearly a year after China signed a security pact with the Solomon Islands, which had raised concerns among Australian officials about the potential for a future Chinese naval presence in the region. y Situated in Oceania, the Solomon Islands consist of approximately 992 small islands, atolls, and reefs. There are six major islands: Choiseul, Guadalcanal, Malaita, Makira, New Georgia, and Santa Isabel....

y Union Home Minister Amit Shah was in Arunachal Pradesh for the launch of the ‘Vibrant Villages Programme’ (VVP) in the border village of Kibithoo. y The program aims to improve the quality of life for people living in identified border villages, encourage them to stay in their native locations, and thereby enhance the security of the border. y The focus areas for development include road connectivity, drinking water, electricity (including solar and wind energy), mobile and internet connectivity, tourist centers, multi-purpose centers, healthcare infrastructure, and wellness centers. y Kibithoo has a rich history, especially noted for the sacrifices of Indian soldiers during the 1962 war with China. It was also a point of supply for Tibetan villagers before the war. y The Meyors tribe constitutes a considerable segment of Kibithoo’s populace, playing a pivotal role in shaping the region’s distinct cultural essence....

y Fuego volcano is an active stratovolcano in Guatemala that has recently erupted violently and buried several villages on its southern flank. y The Volcán de Fuego, or “Volcano of Fire,” is a highly active stratovolcano located in Guatemala. It’s known for its frequent and often continuous activity, including gas and ash explosions that occur every 15 to 20 minutes. y Fuego has erupted frequently, with notable eruptions in June and November 2018, September 2021, December 2022, and as recently as May 2023. y The volcano is part of the Central American Volcanic Arc and has a history of eruptions dating back to prehistoric times. Its eruptions have been more mafic in recent times compared to older eruptions....

y The so-called “laundromat” countries are countries that buy Russian oil and sell processed products to European countries, thus sidestepping European sanctions against Russian Oil. y The five countries (India, China, Turkey, UAE and Singapore) are identified as ‘laundromats’ for Western countries by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA). y The five countries are responsible for 70 percent of Russia’s crude oil exports....

y It is located in the Southwestern Barents Sea at the Outer Bear Island Trough. y The Borealis Mud Volcano is a recently discovered geological phenomenon located in the Barents Sea, south of Norway’s Bear Island. y It was identified on May 7, 2023, by an underwater rover....

y Tam Pà Ling Cave in the Annamite Mountain range in Northern Laos has recently provided groundbreaking insights into the timeline of human arrival in Southeast Asia. y Tam Pà Ling Cave, also known as the Cave of the Monkeys, is an archaeological site located in the Annamite Mountains in northeastern Laos. y It is situated at the top of Pa Hang Mountain, at an altitude of 1,170 meters (3,840 feet) above sea level. y The cave has yielded three hominin fossils, which represent three separate individuals dating from around 70,000 to 46,000 years old. These findings suggest that modern humans may have migrated to Southeast Asia by 60,000 BP. y Tam Pà Ling is part of a network of karst caves, formed by the dissolution of limestone beds dating back to the Upper Carboniferous and Permian periods. y Excavations have uncovered a skull (TPL1) belonging to an anatomically modern human, a mandible (TPL2) with both modern and archaic traits, and a partial mandible (TPL3) with similar mixed features...

y It is a city located in the European part of Russia. The Report was launched by Convention of Migratory Species of Wild Animals: y Migratory species are declining globally. y 97% of listed fish face extinction risk. y Greatest threats: Overexploitation and loss of natural habitat. y Climate change, pollution, and invasive species also impact migratory species. y Urged actions include: y Combating illegal and unsustainable hunting/capture. y Identifying, protecting, and connecting critical habitats. y Tackling climate change, pollution, and other threats. y Expanding CMS listings to include more at-risk species....

question_text: A study estimated a timescale for the collapse of the Gulf Stream between 2025 and 2095, with a central estimate of 2050, if global Carbon emissions are not reduced: y The Gulf Stream is a powerful ocean current in the North Atlantic Ocean. y It originates in the Gulf of Mexico and flows northeastward along the eastern coast of the United States, then across the Atlantic towards Europe. y It plays a significant role in regulating the climate by transporting warm water and heat. y Importance and Impact: y Climate Regulation. y Can lead to extreme weather patterns such as storms or hurricanes. It can also contribute to the formation of fog in certain areas. y Provides a fast and efficient route for ships traveling between North America and Europe....

y Classification: Belongs to the bamboo tail group y Status: Considered near-threatened according to the IUCN Red List y Endemism: Found exclusively in the Western Ghats region y Habitat: Recorded only between the Nilgiri Hills and Sharavathi Valley y Genus: Sole described species of the genus Phylloneura...

y Definition: Anoxic marine basins are bodies of water without oxygen, making them viable for large-scale carbon sequestration in the deep ocean. y Examples: Black Sea, Cariaco Trench, Baltic Sea. y Formation: y Stratification: Density differences (salt or temperature) create layers, impeding vertical mixing and oxygen replenishment. y Organic matter decomposition: Microbes consume oxygen while breaking down organic matter, depleting levels. y Limited circulation: Restricted flow from surrounding oxygenated waters. y Types: y Permanent: Anoxia persists year-round. y Temporary: Anoxia occurs seasonally or during specific events. y Ecological Impact: y Oxygen scarce: Few animals can survive. y Microbial haven: Thriving microbes form the food chain base. y Play a role in global cycles: Carbon, nitrogen, and other elements....

y India is both the largest producer and importer. y Also known as arhar and tur in India. y Predominantly grown in semi-arid regions. y Requirements: y Rainfall: Needs 600-650mm annually, with initial moist conditions (8 weeks) and dry periods during flowering and pod development. y Temperature: Prefers warm temperatures, ranging from 26-30°C during the rainy season and 17-22°C post-rainy season (November to March). y Soil: Adapts to various soils, but thrives best in sandy loam or loam. y Light: Sensitive to low light during pod development, so flowering during monsoon or cloudy weather can hinder pod formation. y Health benefits: y Low glycemic index. y Rich in thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin B-6, folate, vitamin A, calcium, zinc, iron, magnesium, and phosphorus. y Major producing states: Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal, Bihar, and Jharkhand....

question_text: Goa became the 1st state to get the World Bank backed Sub National Climate Resilient Green Fund. y Sub National Climate Resilient Green Fund: y A global blended finance initiative. y Develops mid-size climate resilient infrastructure & nature-based solutions. y Aims to catalyze climate mitigation and adaptation solutions at the subnational level through a transformative finance model. Green Climate Fund: y Structure: y Fund Manager: Pegasus Capital. y Technical assistance: International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). y Anchor Investor of Concessional Capital: The Green Climate Fund (GCF). y Set up in 2010 under UNFCCC. y Allows funding from developed countries to developing countries for climate change mitigation. y Targets vulnerable societies. y Target Impact: y Enable access to clean & affordable energy and water. y Reduce CO2 emissions. y Support education and economic growth. y Support a circular economy. y Sustainably manage and restore natural and modified ecosystems....

question_text: y First breeding population discovered along the Chandragiri River in Kera. y Also known as the Asian giant softshell turtle and the frog-faced softshell turtle. y Found in eastern and southern India, Bangladesh, Burma, and other Southeast Asian countries. y Inhabits slow-moving freshwater rivers, lakes, and estuaries. y Conservation Status: Critically Endangered (IUCN), Appendix II (CITES), Schedule I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. y Chandragiri River: y Also known as the Perumpuzha River. y Longest river in Kasaragod district, Kerala. y Originates from the Talakaveri Wildlife Sanctuary in the Western Ghats of Kodagu district, Karnataka....

The high-level committee for Yamuna’s rejuvenation sets a target for floodplain’s demarcation. y Definition: A floodplain is a flat area of land beside a river or stream, stretching from the riverbanks to the valley’s outer edges. y Components: y Floodway: Main channel of the river, sometimes seasonal. y Flood Fringe: Extends from outer banks of floodway to the bluff. Types of Floodplains in India: y Peninsular: Found in Deccan plateau with rock terraces. y Himalayan: Old, wide, and depositional, formed by sediment deposition. y Natural Processes in Floodplain Development: y Erosion: Earth worn away by movement of floodways. y Aggradation (Alluviation): Increase in earthen material as floodway deposits sediment....

The Climate and Clean Air Conference, 2024 emphasized international collaboration for phasing out Short-Lived Climate Pollutants (SLCPs): y It is an annual event hosted by the Climate and Clean Air Coalition (CCAC), comprising over 160 governments and organizations dedicated to SLCP reduction. y SLCPs are pollutants with short atmospheric lifespans but significant warming effects on the climate. y They contribute up to 45% of current global warming, second only to CO2 emissions. y Major sources of SLCPs include inefficient fuel combustion, the agricultural sector, waste management, and refrigeration/cooling processes....

question_text: Scientists have discovered that North Atlantic right whales are getting smaller, impacting their ability to breed. y Geoengineering or climate engineering approach to mitigate global warming effects. Prime Minister of India, in the 103rd edition of Mann ki Baat, spotlighted the business of ‘bhojpatra calligraphy’ by Mana village women near Badrinath. y Bhojpatra, or Himalayan Birch, grows at elevations of 3,000m or higher. y Its bark serves as paper for writing text due to its unique properties. y The women of Mana village utilize bhojpatra for calligraphy, showcasing traditional skills and fostering entrepreneurship. y This initiative reflects the promotion of indigenous crafts and economic empowerment of local communities. y Also known as Himalayan Birch, this deciduous tree thrives in the Himalayas, growing at elevations of up to 4,500 meters. y Possessing high freezing tolerance, it forms a treeline in the Himalayan region, crucial for the ecosystem. y A long-lived species, it can endure for up to 400 years, unique among angiosperms in dominating extensive sub-alpine areas. y Distribution: Widely found in the altitudinal range of 3100 - 3800 m in the North-western Himalaya. y I...

Conservative voices in Japan suggest that the conflict between Russia and Ukraine might provide an opportunity for Japan to assert control over the disputed Kuril Islands. y Location: Kuril Islands are situated between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Pacific Ocean, near Japan’s northernmost prefecture, Hokkaido. y Names: Japan refers to them as Northern Territories, Russia calls them the Kuril Islands, and South Korea named them Dokdo Islands. y Geological Features: Part of the Pacific Ring of Fire belt, they boast over 100 volcanoes, with 35 classified as active, and are rich in hot springs. y Sovereignty Dispute: Both Russia and Japan claim sovereignty over the islands, which have been under Russian control since the end of World War II. The Soviet Union seized them at the war’s end and expelled Japanese residents by 1949. Tokyo argues that the islands have been Japanese territory since the early 19th century....

y India surpassed Brazil as the largest sugar producer in 2021-2022, reaching 359 lakh tonnes. y Reasons for excess sugar production include high consumption, government policies like Fair and Remunerative Price (FRP) for sugarcane, and heavy subsidies. y Excessive sugarcane cultivation exacerbates groundwater depletion, particularly in top sugarcane-growing states like Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka, Gujarat, and Tamil Nadu. y A 2022 report by the Central Ground Water Board (CGWB) highlighted that a significant portion of groundwater assessment units in Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, and Karnataka were in a critical or over-exploited state due to sugarcane cultivation....

Experts caution pesticide sellers about glyphosate due to its carcinogenic properties. y About Glyphosate: ⚪ Widely used herbicide effective against certain weeds and grasses. ⚪ Primarily used in agriculture, forestry, and lawn/garden care. ⚪ Composed of a linear carbon chain with weaker bonds, making it less persistent in the environment. ⚪ Known brands in India: Roundup, Glycel, Brake. ⚪ Effective only on plants above water level, ineffective on submerged or largely underwater plants. y Systemic Nature of Glyphosate: ⚪ Absorbed by plant leaves and translocated throughout the vascular system. ⚪ Reaches various plant parts including roots, effectively controlling both above and below-ground plant parts. ⚪ Slow degradation in plants, potential residues in food products....

y Withstood dinosaurs and other prehistoric eras y Now facing threat from climate change y Moss species within genus endangered y Highlighting vulnerability of ancient plant life to modern challenges About Takakia: y Rare genus of moss adapted to high altitudes over millions of years. y Appearance resembles a layer of moss or green algae from afar, but closer inspection reveals slender turf around 1 cm in length with short, finger-like leaves. y Consists of only two species, T. lepidozioides and T. ceratophylla, both found exclusively in the Tibetan Plateau. y Developed survival abilities against frost, UV radiation, and other harsh conditions. y Combination of features from mosses, liverworts, and green algae. y Separated from other mosses 390 million years ago, shortly after the first land plants evolved....

About Solar Energy Corporation of India Limited (SECI): y SECI is a Central Public Sector Undertaking (CPSU) under the administrative control of the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE). y It was established to facilitate the implementation of the National Solar Mission (NSM) and its set targets. y SECI is the only CPSU dedicated solely to the renewable energy sector. y Vision: To build a ‘Green India’ by harnessing abundant solar radiation and achieving energy security for the country. y Mission: ⚪ To lead in the development of large-scale solar installations, solar plants, and solar parks, promoting the use of solar energy across India. ⚪ To pioneer new technologies for harnessing solar energy and their deployment....

y The last survivors of the Piripkura tribe were found in Brazil’s Mato Grosso region: y The Piripkura tribe is known for its nomadic lifestyle and efforts to preserve its traditional way of life. y Encroachment on their land by illegal logging, mining, and other activities has posed significant challenges to the tribe. y Their territory has been under threat from deforestation and resource extraction. y Finding the last survivors raises questions about how to protect their rights and preserve their culture. y Efforts may include establishing protected areas, advocating for indigenous rights, and addressing the underlying causes of land exploitation....

question_text: Aims to finance the implementation of Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (KMGBF). y Governance of GBFF ⚪ Decisions taken by consensus by GBFF Council, akin to the GEF Instrument. y Financial Management ⚪ The World Bank was invited as a Trustee of GBFF. ⚪ Modeled after funds like the Capacity-Building Initiative for Transparency (CBIT) Trust Fund, Least Developed Countries (LDCs) Fund, Special Climate Change Fund, and Nagoya Protocol Implementation Fund (NPIF). y Features of GBFF ⚪ Mobilizes and disburses capital from public, private, and philanthropic sources, focusing on biodiversity and ecosystem sustainability. ⚪ 20% of funds allocated to support Indigenous-led initiatives. y Prioritization ⚪ Focuses on support for Small Island Developing States and LDCs....

It is a starch extracted from the pith of a variety of palm trees, has been granted the Geographical indication (GI) tag by the Indian government. y Salem Sago, locally known as Javvarisi, is produced in the Salem district of Tamil Nadu, India. y It is recognized as Sabudana in Indian cuisine. y Derived from wet starch powder obtained by crushing and extracting starch from tapioca roots. y Granted a Geographical Indication (GI) tag, signifying its unique qualities and connection to Salem district. y Over 80% of India’s sago production is from Salem region, with a significant portion marketed through Sagoserve....

About Schizostachyum andamanicum: y Discovered on the Andaman island about three decades ago. y Found only in some forested areas of Andamans. y Primarily grows in the wet tropical biome. y Characterized by thin, large hollow erect culms (stems) with long internodes; potential for developing into a straw. y Bears small, white flowers arranged in clusters; seeds are small and black; seedlings have thin, light green leaves. Botanical Survey of India: y Apex taxonomic research organization of India. y Operates under the Ministry of Environment, Forest & Climate Change, Government of India. y Established on 13th February 1890 under the direction of Sir George King. y Mandate includes biosystematics research, floristic studies, documentation, databasing of National Botanical collection, digitization of herbarium spec...

Recent studies suggest a potential rise in global thunderstorm activity. This increase could lead to a higher quantity of wispy cirrus clouds. The formation of these clouds may accelerate global warming. Characteristics of Cirrus Clouds: y Delicate, feathery clouds primarily composed of ice crystals. y Thin and wispy in appearance, resembling high-altitude filaments. y Shaped by wind currents, which twist and spread ice crystals into strands. y Often referred to as “mare’s tails” due to their resemblance to a horse’s tail. y Typically found at heights exceeding 20,000 feet (6,000 meters). y Composed of ice crystals originating from the freezing of supercooled water droplets. y Commonly observed in fair weather conditions and indicate air movement at their elevation....
